Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo G9P6 who was transferred from ___ 
___ on ___ with contractions concerning for preterm labor. 
Her contractions became progressively stronger and more painful 
and she was noted to dilate her cervix to 5cm. An ultrasound  
revealed breech presentation of the presenting twin. As a 
result, the decision was made to proceed to the operating room 
for cesarean delivery. Patient thus underwent an uncomplicated 
repeat low transverse cesarean section. Please see operative 
note for details.

Her post operative course was uncomplicated. By post operative 
day 4, patient reached all her post operative milestones. She 
was thus discharged to home in stable condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
- PNV
- Iron supplement 
- ASA 81 mg daily 
- Miralax PRN
- Tums PRN 
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0 
3.  Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Moderate 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours 
Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
34 week gestation, twins, malpresentation, history of cesarean 
delivery, preterm labor

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Nothing in the vagina for 6 weeks (No sex, douching, tampons)
No heavy lifting for 6 weeks
Do not drive while taking narcotics (i.e. Dilaudid, Percocet)
Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (tylenol) in 24 hrs
Do not take more than 2400mg ibuprofen in 24 hrs
Please call the on-call doctor at ___ if you develop 
shortness of breath, dizziness, palpitations, fever of 100.4 or 
above, abdominal pain, increased redness or drainage from your 
incision, nausea/vomiting, heavy vaginal bleeding, or any other 
concerns.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ is a ___ year old G4 P0 who presented at 38w6d in 
labor. She had an vaginal delivery ___ of a liveborn male 
infant. Her post partum course was complicated by nausea and 
vomiting likely due to gastroenteritis. There was low suspicion 
for ileus/small bowel obstruction. Her nausea/vomiting improved 
with medication and she was able to tolerate PO. Her 
electrolytes, LFT were reassuring. She was discharged home in 
stable condition on post partum day 4.

The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY

1. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY

per written instructions reviewed by nursing

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Calcium Channel Blocking Agent Diltiazem Analogues
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Stroke
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yr F w/ hx of ESRD on HD, HTN, DMII, and prior stroke in 
___ w/ residual mild aphasia who was transferred from OSH due 
to new onset R sided weakness and profound aphasia concerning 
for stroke. Exam is consistent with a L MCA syndrome w/ pt seen
to have severe expressive aphasia, L gaze preference, and R 
sided weakness. NIHSS at OSH was 22, tPA was given at OSH at 
___ on ___. NIHSS on ___ was 18. Etiology could potentially 
cardioembolic, given recurrent stroke and proximal vasculature
appearing clear on affected side. Her 24 hour head CT showed 
large L MCA
infarct, with no hemorrhage. Based on the CTA would not have 
expected the entire territory to infarct, as she had what 
appeared to be relatively good distal reconstitution. She has a 
fetal PCA on the L and appeared to be supplying her MCA from 
there. Her infarct is quite large now, affecting both the 
cortical motor areas and subcortical fibers and would expect 
that she remain hemiplegic on the R. She exam developed into a 
global aphasia and hemiplegia on the R. Goals of care were 
discussed with family, and she was made comfort measures only. 
She passed away ___ at 7:07am. 

#ESRD - she received HD while she was here, renal was consulted 
for management. Per family request, this was discontinued when 
goals were shifted to comfort measures only.

#yeast in peritoneal fluid - yeast grew in peritoneal fluid 
culture from ___. She was started on fluconazole, ID was 
consulted. This was discontinued after she was made CMO

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
2. coenzyme Q10 100 mg oral DAILY 
3. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO DAILY 
4. Furosemide 40 mg PO DAILY 
5. glimepiride 1 mg oral BID 
6. HydrALAZINE 50 mg PO BID 
7. Labetalol 600 mg PO BID 
8. NIFEdipine (Extended Release) 60 mg PO BID 
9. Sodium Bicarbonate 650 mg PO DAILY 
10. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 
11. CloNIDine 0.1 mg PO DAILY 
12. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY

Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Stroke
 
Discharge Condition:
Passed away
 
Discharge Instructions:
N/A

washout and repair of injured structures, ORIF R thumb fracture.

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr ___ is a healthy RHD ___ yo M who sustained a table injury 
to the Hand with lacerations to all 5 finger tips, the most 
severe of which was to thumb at the level of the IP joint that 
required wash out, repair and exploration in the OR.  
 
Past Medical History:
None

___

na
 
Physical Exam:
The distal thumb tip is warm and well perfused with good cap 
refill and no/minimal sensation
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ was admitted to the hand surgery service on ___ and taken to the Operating room with Dr ___ night 
for a repair and wash out of injured structures to the R hand 
following a table saw injury to the R hand.  Please see 
separately dictated note for details of the procedure.  He 
tolerated the procedure well and was recovered initially in the 
pacu and then on the surgical floor without issues.  He was 
maintained on aspirin 121.5, and subq heparin with the hand 
under a bair hugger for 2 days.  The thumb remained warm and 
well perfused with brisk cap refill.  It was largely insensate.  
On POD2 he was pain controlled on PO pain meds, voiding and 
ambulating independently.  His splint was clean, dry and intact. 
 He was then discharged from the hospital in a good condition.  
 
Medications on Admission:
none

take for 30 days

4.  Ibuprofen 400 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Moderate  
5.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity 
6.  Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY:PRN constipation

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted on ___ after outside CT showed a L3 
compression fracture with retropulsion. The patient was 
neurologically intact on admission.

On ___, the patient remained hemodynamically and neurologically 
stable. ___ was fitted for an LSO and got standing AP and lateral

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L3 compression fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Alert and oriented x3
Ambulatory

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have a fracture of your lumbar spine. 
- An MRI was done to ensure that there were no underlying 
problems with your bone causing the fracture. A final read of 
this MRI is still pending. Dr. ___ will call if there are any 
concerning findings.
- You must wear your brace at all times out of bed. You may come 
out of the brace only for quick showers and when laying in bed.
- Please avoid any strenuous activities until your follow up 
visit. No lifting, running.
- Please avoid taking any blood thinners like aspirin or 
coumadin or any anti-inflammatory medications/NSAIDs such as 
ibuprofen, naproxen until cleared to by your neurosurgeon.
- Please take Tylenol for any minor pain.
- You can take Tramadol as prescribed for any pain not relieved 
by Tylenol. Please decrease the amount of tramadol you are 
taking as your pain improves.
- Please avoid drinking or driving while taking Tramadol.
- If you are constipation, consider taking a stool softer or 
laxative like Colace or Senna, most available over the counter 
at your local drugstore. Also keeping well hydrated will improve 
constipation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ___ former smoker (___) who 
presented with dry cough for the past six months. Evaluation for 
this included a chest CT ___ which showed a right upper lobe 
mass with associated paratracheal lymphadenopathy. She underwent 
EBUS/TBNA ___ that had path of the RUL mass return as 
keratinizing squamous cell ca. Level 4R and 7 were negative. Her 
PET-CT ___ noted an FDG avid (SUV 20) 5.5 x 6.5 cm right 
upper lobe mass abutting mediastinal and parietal pleura. She 
underwent right thoracotomy and right pneumonectomy 
___ by pseudomonas PNA and respiratory failure 
s/p trach/PEG (___). With recurrent worsening left lung 
consolidation and being treated for PNA. She was discharged to 
rehab earlier today and returned to the hospital with acute 
respiratory failure likely secondary to morphine and Ativan 
administration

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was discharged to rehab on ___ after prolonged 
hospital stay s/p pneumonectomy.  However, a few hours after 
arriving at the rehab facility, the patient desaturated to 70% 
on 100$ FiO2, and was brought back to the hospital for urgent 
bronchoscopy.  Bronchoscopy in the ED was negative for mucus 
plugging but was questionable for a malacia component and pt was 
admitted to the TSICU.  She underwent Lasix diuresis, and was 
weaned to pressure support.  However, on ___ after a 
bronchoscopy by IP that did not reveal TBM, she desaturated to 
70% once again and underwent emergent bronchoscopy in the ICU 
which was again negative.  She was put back on a ventilator rate 
and Palliative care, Dr. ___ the ___ family had 
multiple conversations regarding the low likelihood of the 
patient getting off the vent.  It was decided that she would not 
undergo any further escalation of care aside from vent 
adjustments to give additional family members a chance to get to 
the hospital to say goodbye.  On ___ Ms ___ was made 
comfortable with family at bedside, and on ___ she passed away.

acute respiratory failure

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the ICU for monitoring. He initially 
refused percutaneous cholecystostomy, stating he did not want 
any invasive treatment. He was started on antibiotics and fluids 
for resuscitation. The following morning, he decided to have the 
procedure. He underwent percutaneous cholecystostomy and was 
brought back to the ICU. Following the procedure, he became 
acutely hypotensive. He was started on blood pressure medication 
and labs revealed an acute decrease in hematocrit and severe 
lactic acidosis. At this time the patient decided he did not 
want any further invasive procedures or escalation of care. He 
passed aware shortly there after.

Discharge Instructions:
-Avoid heavy lifting (nothing more than 5 lbs), strenuous 
activity or exercise for 4 weeks after surgery.
-Avoid raising your right arm above shoulder height, overhead 
reaching, or using your right arm to lift yourself up from the 
seated or lying position.
-Walking after surgery is encouraged as it helps to reduce the 
risk of infectious complications as well as blood clots.  

-Drain care as reviewed during your admission.  Strip and empty 
drains twice daily. Record output for each individual drain in a 
log. Bring this log to your first postoperative follow up 
appointment. 

-Monitor your wounds daily for signs of infection including 
redness, drainage, swelling, increasing pain, fever > ___.  
-You may sponge bather.  However, keep all surgical wounds, 
drain sites and surgical dressings dry.

normotensive and tachycardic sent immediately to CT imaging 
unremarkable. EKG shows peaked T waves consistent with 
hyperkalemia. CK elevated secondary to severe rhabdomyolysis.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was taken to the ___ on ___. His Hct on admission 
had dropped significantly to 17.9 from 31.9, which was thought 
to be dilutional due to aggressive fluid resuscitation. His 
bilateral lower extremities were noted to be tense and so a 
fasciotomy was performed at bedside by the orthopedic service. 
However, the incisions continued to exsanguinate profusely and 
so orthopedics reevaluated the incisions with the ACS service 
multiple times without a notable focal bleeding site. Diffuse 
oozing was due to the coagulopathy, which was aggressively 
attempted to be corrected with a massive transfusion protocol. 
On ___, his abdomen was also noted to have increased 
pressure, as shown by his elevated bladder pressure, and so an 
emergent ex-lap was performed with Abthera vac placement. He 
continued to require higher vent settings during this time and 
was on CRRT since admission for his hyperkalemia. However, his 
hyperkalemia continued to get worsened despite aggressive 
correction. He also had received a repeat head CT on ___ 
for concern of unequal pupils, but was stable. On ___, 
patient showed widened complex and coded. ACLS was performed for 
about 1.5-2hrs with aggressive correction of hyperkalemia. 
Patient was finally pronounced dead on ___ at 0255.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ Ms. ___ underwent primary low transverse cesarean 
section. Her pain was treated with oral pain medications. She 
ambulated and her foley was discontinued and she voided 
spontaneously. She had an episode of dizziness with ambulation 
post-operatively, with positive orthostatic vital signs. Her 
hematocrit was found to be 28.3, and her symptoms resolved on 
their own. Her diet was advanced without incident. 

For her gestational diabetes, her blood glucose was monitored. 
On post-partum day 3 she was found to have elevated blood 
pressures. Her PIH labs were normal, and notable for an 
equivocal urine P:C ratio of < 0.6. She was started on 
Nifedipine twice daily for blood pressure control and her blood 
pressures were monitored closely. She was given one dose of 
Lasix for lower extremity swelling, and experienced symptomatic 
relief. She was also seen by Social Work during her admission. 

By postpartum day 5, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

encephalopathy caused by new aggressive liver cancer.

the possible side effects and unlikely long term benefit, family 
declined.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service for 
conservative management of recurrent diverticulitis. He was made 
NPO, given IVF and IV antibiotics. His abdominal exam was 
closely monitored. His vital signs were closely monitored and he 
was afebrile and hemodynamically stable throughout the course of 
his hospitalization. When his tenderness was resolving, his diet 
was slowly advanced as tolerated to a regular diet. He was 
transitioned from IV to oral antibiotics. He was voiding and 
ambulating without difficulty. On HD#2 he was tolerating oral 
medications and a regular diet and his abdominal exam had 
improved. He was felt to be appropriate for discharge. 

He will follow-up with ACS and/or colorectal surgery to discuss 
further management of recurrent diverticulitis. The patient 
verbalized understanding of the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your 
hospitalization!

WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED?
- You were having bloody bowel movements.

WHAT HAPPENED DURING YOUR HOSPITALIZATION?
- You had imaging that didn't show any active bleeding, but did 
show diverticulosis.
- Your blood counts and vital signs were stable. Your GIB slowed 
down. 
- You were seen by the GI, and you are scheduled for an 
outpatient colonoscopy tomorrow. 

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO ONCE YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?
- Please complete the bowel prep per instructions from GI. (You 
should receive a phone call.) 
- Please come back to the emergency room if you have continued 
or worsening bloody bowel movements (or have any of the danger 
signs listed below). 
- Please don't strain when having a bowel movement! Try using an 
over the counter stool softener/laxative like Miralax or Senna 
to prevent straining. 
- Follow up with all of your doctors as noted below.

Again, it was a pleasure taking care of you!

All the best,
Your ___ Team

Brief Hospital Course:
She underwent a normal vaginal delivery on ___. She had 
an abruption during labor, and the placenta was delivered 
spontaneously intact.  After delivery of the placenta, there was 
passage of a large amount of post-placental clot.  There
then was manual evacuation of another large amount of clots from 
the uterus right after delivery under anesthesia using fentanyl 
IV alone.  After that, she was given 1000 mcg of Cytotec.  She 
responded well, and there was minimal bleeding. Three hours 
later, she was noted to have a uterine fundus that was rising 
and reaccumulation of blood clots.  Decision was made to go to 
the operating room for manual extraction of these clots, as the 
epidural anesthetic was not working.

She underwent MAC anesthesia, and ultrasound showed clot in the 
intrauterine cavity. Under direct visualization, there was 
manual removal of another 200 cc of clot.  Manual removal was 
then completed, and it was noted that there was a clear
endometrial stripe.  There was some brief uterine atony, and 
that was treated with 0.2 mg of Methergine IM.  Tone was then 
excellent and bleeding halted, and the procedure was called to a 
close.

Her postpartum course was otherwise uncomplicated. Her pain was 
treated with oral pain medications. She ambulated and her foley 
was discontinued and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was 
advanced without incident. 

By postpartum day 3, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was transferred to labor and delivery 
from ___ for preterm contractions. On arrival she was 
found to be 1 cm dilated. She had an amniocentesis that was 
notable for low glucose, therefore concerning for 
chorioamnionitis. The decision was made to keep patient 
overnight for serial vaginal exams and start her on ampicilin 
and gentamicin. She was seen by the NICU and received 
counseling. Overnight she developed worsening cramping and was 
found to have made cervical change with a bulging amniotic bag. 
She received an epidural and subsequently had a previable 
preterm vaginal delivery. Post-partum she received one 
additional dose of ampicillin and gentamicin and was seen by 
spiritual care and social work. She was discharged home on 
___ with appropriate follow-up scheduled.

Name:  ___             Unit No:  ___

DATE OF ADMISSION:  ___

DATE OF DISCHARGE:  ___

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a ___
gravida 4, para 2, who presents at 38 and two weeks with
painful contractions beginning every seven minutes and now
progressing to every 3 minutes.  The patient's prenatal course
is notable for vaginal culture for group B strep that was
positive with a plan for prophylaxis in labor and earlier in
pregnancy a shortened cervix noted on her fetal survey.  In
the second trimester, the patient was on vaginal progesterone
until about two weeks prior to her presentation here.  She had
no episodes or symptoms of preterm labor. 
EDC is ___
by first trimester ultrasound.  Prenatal labs include blood
type of A positive, antibody negative, hep B surface antigen
negative, rubella immune, varicella immune, treponemal
antibody is negative.  HIV negative, hep C antibody is
negative.  Her glucose screening was 139.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Negative for hypertension, obesity,
diabetes, liver or renal disease.  She has no thyroid
dysfunction.

SURGICAL HISTORY:  Negative.

OBSTETRIC HISTORY:  Includes normal vaginal delivery at term,
x2 and termination x2.

GYNECOLOGIC HISTORY:  Includes a Pap smear last done in ___
that was negative for abnormalities.  No history of STDs.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  No alcohol, drugs or tobacco use.

MEDICATIONS:  Prenatal vitamins once a day.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
VITAL SIGNS:  Blood pressure is 118/72, heart rate is 92,
temperature is 98.7.
GENERAL:  She is well appearing, in no distress, but
uncomfortable with contractions.  LUNGS:  Respiratory rate has
normal function with clear lung.
HEART:  Regular rate and rhythm.
ABDOMEN:  Soft, gravid and nontender, vertex by ___.
EXTREMITIES:  No calf tenderness or erythema bilaterally. 
Cervical exam on admission, cervix was 5 cm with the vertex in
-2 station.  Membranes are intact.  Tocometer shows
contractions every 3 minutes.  Fetal heart rate tracing is
category 2, 135 baseline with moderate variability with
accelerations, isolated decelerations that appeared late in
timing of present.  Bedside ultrasound was also performed that
was confirmed a vertex presentation.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted to the labor and
delivery floor and observed for progress in labor.  Shortly
after her presentation, the patient was noted to be fully
dilated and the baby crowning and the patient delivered a
viable baby girl without complication.  She had a superficial
periurethral laceration that was hemostatic.  The placenta was
delivered spontaneously.  Estimated blood loss was 200 mL. 
The patient was then transferred to the postpartum floor where
she did well in her postpartum recovery over the subsequent
two days.  On postpartum day #2, she was doing well,
ambulating, able to void with no complication and minimal to
normal lochia and was appropriate for discharge home.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:  Ibuprofen one 600 mg tab
every six hours p.r.n. pain and prenatal vitamin once a day.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:  Pregnancy at term, normal vaginal
delivery, viable baby girl.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:
# Sepsis ___ cellulitis

Patient presented with sepsis with leukocytosis, fever. She had 
erythema and tenderness of her left upper arm and shoulder. 
This all occurred after she received vaccines in both her 
shoulders. 

She was initially started on vancomycin in the ED, but erythema 
reportedly worsened. She was then broadened to ceftriaxone and 
clindamycin. 
Since then her WBC and physical exam have resolved. She still 
has some mild erythema on her arm. 
She had an xray of her shoulder that was done to look for gas 
and was normal. 
She did not have any palpable collections on exam, so US was 
deferred. 

She was discharged on clindamycin and cefpodoxime to complete a 
7 day course. 

Patient received several liters of NS in the ED. All of her cell 
counts went down during hospital course. Her Hgb came down to 9 
without signs of bleeding. She should follow up with her PCP to 
recheck her CBC in ___ weeks.

Brief Hospital Course:
On admission, the patient no longer had any respiratory 
symptoms, and was saturating well both standing and while lying 
down. Therefore, the plan for a thoracentesis was canceled. Both 
the hematology and acute care surgery teams were consulted, who 
recommended an excisional biopsy of his right inguinal node. 
This showed lymphoma. In preparation for possible chemotherapy, 
he had a TTE which was normal. HIV and Hep C serologies were 
negative, and his Hep B serologies were consistent with a 
cleared infection. An SPEP was sent, and is pending. Ultimately, 
the hematology team recommended that the patient remain 
inpatient while awaiting immunophenotyping, with concerns for an 
aggressive lymphoma. However, the patient strongly desired to 
return home and follow up as an outpatient. The risks of leaving 
were discussed, including the risk of decompensation or death, 
and the patient stated that he understood. As he has capacity to 
make his own decisions, he was therefore discharged, and will 
follow up with the hematology team as an outpatient.

> 30 minutes spent on discharge activities.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year old gentleman with history of coronary
disease who presented with atypical chest pain. 

We reviewed recent stress testing which was notable for 
reversible inferior ischemia. Presentation and cardiac enzyme 
pattern not consistent with acute coronary syndrome and is 
discomfort during this presentation was much different then the 
chest pain consistent with angina he had earlier in the week 
when he presented with NSTEMI. 

GIven he was not gaing ACS and had no angina this 
hospitalization we advised medical management.  We attempted to 
start medical management but the patient left abruptly before he 
could be sent with prescriptions.  Of note he had been deemed to 
have capacity to make his own medical decisions by psychiatry 
team during the hospitalization last week and his mental status 
had not changed.

We would recommend treatment with: 
Metoprolol succinate 25mg daily, aspirin 81mg daily, clopidogrel 
75mg daily, a
atorvastatin 80mg daily.  We urged him to wait for meds to bed 
but he refused.

pain and nausea. She was then transferred to ___ given her 
proctocolectomy was performed here. On interview she is at this 
point passing gas readily and feeling much improved. Her NGT was 
clamped for several hours and when reattached to suction put out 
approximately 100 mL of thin bilious fluid. Her abdomen is soft, 
non-distended and non-tender. There is no evidence of stricture 
or anastamotic defect on DRE. Labs taken in the ED showed a 
leukocytosis to 15 but only minor metabolic derangements.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented with a week of fevers (TMax 100.4 at 
home) and hypoxic respiratory failure, not improving despite two 
days of oral antibiotics at home. A CXR was performed, which 
showed a LLL opacification. He was started on empiric CAP 
coverage -- ceftriaxone and azithromycin. His symptoms improved 
dramatically, his leukocytosis downtrended, and on HD#2 he was 
off oxygen. Because of no changes in cough or sputum production, 
he was not treated for a COPD exacerbation. He received four 
days of IV ceftriaxone and azithromycin as an inpatient; because 
he received two days as well as an outpatient, he completed a 
course and did not receive any antibiotics on discharge. He will 
follow up with his pulmonologist and his PCP.

HOSPITAL COURSE BY PROBLEM:

1. CAP. Completed course of antibiotics

2. CKD3. At baseline.

3. HTN. Home amlodipine.

4. Low-grade bladder cancer. Will follow up with urology. Did 
have some urinary retention; d/w patient -- previously on 
Tamsulosin, but became orthostatic on medication.

> 30 minutes spent on discharge activities, and patient examined 
on day of discharge.

Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

you.

advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

medications.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, patient underwent a spontaneous vaginal delivery 
complicated by immediate postpartum convulsions. 

For her convulsions, her blood pressures were noted to be normal 
range and her PIH labs were negative. Neurology was consulted 
and there was low suspicion for seizures and the episode was 
thought to be ___ vasovagal convulsions. They did not recommend 
imaging or further treatment. She received 24 hours of 
postpartum magnesium per MFM recommendations. Per MFM 
recommendations she had CBC and lytes drawn which were within 
normal limits. She had an EKG which showed t wave inversions 
consistent with prior EKGs and no workup was recommended per 
cardiology and anesthesia. The remainder of her postpartum 
course was routine.

By postpartum day 3, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

not reveal his real name. For this, social work was consulted 
and and states that he is minimally engaged and disinterested in 
having support. 

Once appropriate Mr. ___ was transferred to the floor for 
further management, and his tertiary exam was determined to be 
negative for additional injury. 

Since being on the floor he has been stable. He denies any pain. 
He was deemed ready for discharge. Before discharge was 
finalized, patient left on his own without informing any staff 
members. He was unable to leave with a script for 2 additional 
days of Keppra which was recommended for seizure prophylaxis.

with Dr. ___. Unfortunately, post procedure chest films 
showed a pneumothorax. An additional chest Xray showed that the 
pneumothorax was progressing and a pigtail chest tube was placed 
by interventional pulmonary team ___. She was admitted to

followed closely. The tube was on suction. All recommendations 
were made by the IP team. We continued to get follow-up chest 
films. This was a very long admission for Mrs. ___ as she 
was feeling really well. On ___ the pneumothorax was finally 
resolved off of suction and the catheter was removed. She was 
discharged home.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

Cervical Spinal Fusion

Surgery
Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery. 
Your incision is closed with staples or sutures. You will need 
suture/staple removal. 
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please keep your incision dry until removal of your 
sutures/staples.
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 
Do NOT smoke. Smoking can affect your healing and fusion.

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc until cleared by your 
neurosurgeon.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ gravida 3 para 2 with a past medical history 
significant for hepatitis C who presents on postpartum day 17 
status post a low transverse cesarean section with incisional 
erythema and purulent drainage concerning for a purulent 
incisional cellulitis.

The patient reports first noticing erythema a few days prior to 
presentation.  She had a wound eval on ___ and was prescribed 
Bactrim.  Since starting the Bactrim she reports that her 
incision has gotten much more red and painful.  She endorses 
oozing onto her underwear.

On physical exam she was afebrile.  Exam was notable for 
erythema along the entire incision extending about 1-2 cm 
inferior to the incision, 1 cm area of right of mid line that 
was intact but with purulent material, and a small 2 mm opening 
about 1 cm superior to the incision to the right of midline with 
purulent yellow serosanguineous drainage.  Fascia was intact.  
The incision was probed in triage.  There was low suspicion for 
a drainable abscess.  Material was sent for wound culture.  The 
patient was admitted for IV antibiotics with vancomycin 
(___) and gentamicin (___) given lack of improvement on 
Bactrim and a history of MRSA positive breast abscesses. 
Preliminary wound culture grew back staph aureus sensitive to 
Bactrim.  After 48 hours on vancomycin she was transitioned to 
p.o. Bactrim.  

On hospital day 3, the patient was afebrile with stable vital 
signs.  She was discharged home on p.o. Bactrim with a plan for 
outpatient follow-up.

vivitrol

delivery and another 200cc in the operating room during removal 
of the placenta. Immediately postpartum, she was initiated on 24 
hours of kefzol.

with acetaminophen and oxycodone. She did well on the floor and 
was initiated on a bowel regimen for her third degree tear. Her 
vital signs remained stable during her hospital stay. She was 
asymptomatic. 

On postpartum day 3, she was tolerating PO pain meds and a 
regular diet, ambulating independently, and voiding 
spontaneously without issue. She was then discharged home in 
stable condition with outpatient follow up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with Crohn's on infliximab here for an elective AVNRT
ablation after sustaining a syncopal event in the setting of
tachycardia. During her procedure she suddenly developed
bradycardia, nausea and shortly thereafter continuous ECG
monitoring demonstrated ST elevations in I, aVL, V2 with 
inferior
STD. She subsequently developed multiple episodes of ventricular
fibrillation requiring defibrillation and CPR >20 minutes before
receiving VA ECMO cannulation ___ RA, FA) with distal 
perfusion
via RSFA. She underwent coronary angiography with OCT which was
notable for a mid-LAD total occlusion with subsequent more
proximal LAD occlusion and a hazy proximal left circumflex
artery. Export thrombectomy and balloon angioplasty was peformed
to the proximal LAD with minimal thrombus; and most consistent
with vasospasm. Her course has been complicated by severe DIC
requiring massive blood transfusions; recurrent VF episodes
requiring relook coronary angiography and further export
thrombectomy; and a progressively rigid abdomen with decreasing
ECMO circuit flow. Vascular surgery, hematology, and general
surgery were consulted for help identifying the cause of her
precipitous blood loss; DIC; and abdominal distention,
respectively. At this time, the patient has been emergently 
taken
by general surgery for an exploratory laparotomy given evidence
of abdominal compartment syndrome leading to ECMO compromise.
DIC may have been precipitated by her cardiac arrest and/or 
liver lacerations. She continued to have VF despite
therapeutic anticoagulation with heparin and repeated coronary
angiograms shows presumed coronary vasospasm +/- small burden of
thrombus.  Her bleeding was unfortunately unable to be 
controlled and thus a family discussion about her grave 
prognosis was held. The patient expired on ___.

Omeprazole 40 mg BID

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was taken emergently to the operating room on ___ 
for surgical
repair of his aortic dissection with an aortic graft and 
resuspension of aortic valve. Please see the operative note for 
details. He was admitted to the cardiac surgery intensive care 
unit with open chest under paralysis and sedation. On the 
evening of surgery he was acidotic and was given fluid 
reccusitation. He has remained sedated and a baseline neurologic 
examination has been unable to be achieved. However, on 
post-operative day one his right pupil was dilated and then 
blown. He received CT noncontrast which showed infarction in the 
right hemisphere with edema and subfalcine and central 
herniation. Neurology and neurosurgery were called for 
therapeutic options and prognostication. Both felt that 
prognosis was very poor and that there was nothing further to be 
done to improve his chances of improvement. The patient's wife 
was called and notified of this change. The family gathered at 
the bedside the following day and decided to withdraw care. He 
expired a short time later.

abuse and Hepatitis C who initially presented with elevated 
blood pressures. She met criteria for pre-eclampsia, with urine 
P/C=0.3 and was admitted for an induction of labor. She 
underwent a spontaneous vaginal delivery on ___. She was 
started on nifedipine 30mg CR daily on postpartum day #2 with 
good blood pressure control. 

On postpartum day #0, pt developed chest pain and upper 
abdominal discomfort. Her blood pressure was 164/91 (137/86 on 
repeat), and the remainder of her vital signs were within normal 
limits. An EKG was done, which revealed normal sinus rhythm. Her 
pain was presumed secondary to reflux and improved with 
famotidine and tums.

Regarding her history of polysubstance abuse (heroin, cocaine), 
pt had a known relapse in pregnancy (urine toxicology screen 
positive for fentanyl on ___. Her initial urine toxicology 
screen on admission was positive for methadone, but otherwise 
negative. She was continued on methadone during this 
hospitalization. She received a nicotine patch for her history 
of cigarette smoking.

The remainder of her postpartum course was uncomplicated. By 
postpartum day #4 she was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating 
independently and her pain was well controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged to home in good condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery chronic htn and superimposed

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ Ms. ___ underwent a vacuum assisted vaginal 
delivery (performed for maternal exhaustion and a category 2 
fetal heart tracing) after an induction of labor for chronic 
hypertension and GDMA1. Her course was complicated by 
superimposed preeclampsia, severe by blood pressures. Her 
initial labs were notable for a P/C of 0.3, with the remainder 
of her preeclampsia labs within normal limits.

On postpartum day #1, pt developed severe range blood pressures 
that did not respond to 10mg PO nifedipine x2. She was 
subsequently started on 24 hours of Magnesium for seizure 
prophylaxis. Pt required an additional 20mg IV labetalol for 
severe range blood pressures and was subsequently started on 
labetalol 200mg PO BID. During the remainder of her postpartum 
course she continued to have blood pressures above goal range 
requiring uptitration of her labetalol to 800mg PO TID on 
postpartum day #3. She received an additional 10mg PO nifedipine 
on postpartum day #3 for severe range blood pressures (183/110). 
On postpartum day#4 her antihypertensive medication regimen was 
changed to labetalol 400mg TID + nifedipine 30mg CR QD. Of note, 
overnight between postpartum day #3 and #4 her labetalol and 
nifedipine were held due to BPs in the 110s-120s/70s.

The remainder of her postpartum course was routine. By 
postpartum day #4 she was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating 
independently, and her pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

PROGRESS NOTE

I am here with ___.  We have been discussing his injuries.
Patient had APC 2 pelvic fracture with symphyseal disruption.
The patient had intraoperative dysrhythmia at his last
surgery and required intraoperative cardioversion, and
accordingly, we fixed the front of the symphysis, but did not
address posteriorly.  A postoperative CT scan reveals a
minimal widening through the posterior SI joint.

I have been discussing with ___, placement of an SI screw
across the right SI joint and the rationale for this as well
as the risks and benefits.  ___ is present for this
dictation.  He and I have gone over this.  ___ weighs 300
pounds.  He is ___ feet 1 inch.  This puts his BMI in the 45
range.  He has a symphyseal plate, but given his elevated
body mass index and his size, I am concerned about the
ability of the hardware to hold him in the front alone.
Certainly, this is procedure which is not without risk.  This
requires good visualization.  If we are able to get good
visualization today, then we will proceed with SI screw
placement.  If we cannot knee adequately with fluoroscopy to
place the screw, then we will not place it.

___ and I have discussed the potential benefits of this in
terms of holding his pelvis stable while it heals.  We have
also discussed the risk.  We have discussed potential
problems with L5 nerve root.  We discussed potential problems
with pelvic surgery in general, including major bleeding
complications and major neurovascular injury.  We discussed
potential for persistent pain and disruption of the SI joint
as well as posterior sacral pain and potential SI joint
arthritis, despite our best efforts, here.  I have discussed
this in detail with ___.  He understands what is involved
here.  He gives informed consent.  We plan to proceed
accordingly.

brain death. The patient was pronounced brain dead when the

managed by the NEOB and the office of the medical examiner from 
that point forward.

Dear Ms. ___:

You were admitted to the hospital with preterm contractions, 
concerning for preterm labor.  Your cervix was examined and 
found to be unchanged. Your contractions became less intense and 
less frequent. You were continued on heparin twice daily for 
your history of thoracic outlet syndrome. For the rest of your 
pregnancy, you should take this instead of Lovenox.  The medical 
team now believes you are safe to be discharged home. Please 
follow the instructions below.

hands, feet, ankles

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
POD #1, patient was orthostatic with ___, BPs 74/50 and improved 
back up to 100/56 laying down. He was asymptomatic. Patient 
administered 500ml IV fluid bolus with appropriate response.

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received Aspirin 325 BID for DVT 
prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The foley was 
removed and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. 
The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical 
incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or 
abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical 
therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and 
repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was 
tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was 
acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral 
regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and 
the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.

intraparenchymal hemorrhage with midline shift, subfalcine and
early uncal herniation. 

She was in her usual state of health until this evening she was
at home watching TV and she got up to go to the bathroom.  After
about 10 minutes her grandson went to check on her because she
had been gone awhile.  When he went to the bathroom he saw her
sitting on the toilet, slumped back and unresponsive.  EMS was
called who found her  unresponsive and she was intubated in the
field with succinylcholine only.  She was given Keppra 1000mg IV
and transferred to the OSH.  There she had a head CT that showed
a large left temporo-parietal IPH with midline shift and early
uncal herniation with blood in the left occipital horn and a
small subdural hematoma.

Initially in the ED her SBPs were in the 150s but steadily
declined to the ___.  Her GCS was 3T and ICH score was 5. 
Neurosurgery was consulted and did not feel an intervention was
indicated in this case given the severity of the bleed and the
grave prognosis.  Neurology was consulted for further 
management.

The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
Overnight on POD#0, the patient experienced a syncopal episode, 
which she triggered for.  EKG was normal, likely was a vasovagal 
episode.  Due to her low blood pressure, she was given a 500 mL 
bolus of fluid.  On POD#1, her blood pressure remained low, so 
she was given another bolus of one-liter of fluid.  

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received Aspirin 325 mg twice 
daily for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The 
foley was removed and the patient was voiding independently 
thereafter. The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the 
surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without 
erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by 
physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital 
course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the 
patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's 
hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on 
an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly 
intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity with posterior precautions. 

 
Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services/rehab in stable 
condition.

On ___ Ms. ___ was admitted to post-partum for left breast 
mastitis and endometritis. Pelvic ultrasound showed 
heterogeneous hypoechoic material ~7mm, avascular, with question 
for retained products. She was started on IV gentamicin and 
clindamycin for 48 hours for her endometritis, and given 
dicloxacillin for her mastitis. There was no evidence of abscess 
on breast exam. By hospital day 2, her leukocytosis and bandemia 
had resolved, and her symptoms were improving, so she was 
transitioned to oral augmentin and flagyl.

oral pain medications, ambulating on her own, and 
symptomatically improving. She was discharged home in stable 
condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

instructions.

Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Allergies/ADRs on File
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Cardiac Arrest
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Needle thoracostomy & chest tube.
CPR
Intubation
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ presented after a witnessed arrest at home. He was 
resuscitated in the field by EMS after an ~30 minute downtime 
(without resuscitation during that time). RoSC was obtained by 
EMS, and he was transferred to the ___ ED. He again coded 5 
more times in the ED, due to PEA arrests, and underwent 5 rounds 
of CPR with intermittent, transient, and vasopressor- and 
inotrope-dependent RoSC before being admitted to the MICU. 
Immediately upon arrival to the ICU, he again suffered PEA 
arrest (while on norepinephrine, epinephrine, vasopressin, and 
phenylephrine infusions), and which CPR and resuscitative 
efforts were again initiated. Despite over 20 minutes of CPR and 
ACLS, RoSC was unable to be achieved, resuscitative efforts were 
halted, and the patietn's wife was informed of his death.
 
Past Medical History:
Unknown
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Unknown
 
Physical Exam:
In cardiac arrest on arrival.

Pupils mid-dilated, fixed. No pulses.
 
Pertinent Results:
In cardiac arrest on arrival; expired
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ experienced cardiac arrest again immediately upon 
admission to the MICU due to PEA. CPR was immediately initiated, 
with over 20 minutes of chest compressions, and multiple doses 
of epinephrine, bicarbonate, and calcium chloride administered 
per ACLS PEA arrest guidelines. Potential reversible causes for 
his recurrent PEA arrests were reviewed by the ICU team, but no 
obvious reversible cause was identified based on the available 
clinical data. Bedside ultrasound did not demonstrated recurrent 
pneumothoraces (he had bilateral chest tubes in place from the 
ED), nor did it demonstrate a significant pericardial effusion 
that would have been suggestive of tamponade. Pulmonary embolism 
was entertained as a possibility, but the risk / benefit 
considerations of systemic t-PA administration were felt to be 
prohibitive as the risk of critical hemorrhage after multiple 
rounds of chest compressions (and chest tubes placement) were 
determined to outweigh any potential benefit. 

In this setting, the consensus decision by all of the ICU health 
care providers participating in his resuscitation was to stop 
CPR and resuscitative efforts. The patient's wife was present at 
the bedside for the majority of his arrest and resuscitative 
efforts, and she endorsed understanding of why CPR was stopped. 
She endorsed understanding that Mr. ___ was dead and that 
ongoing CPR was not beneficial, and that it represented futile 
care. We provided emotional and psychological support, and 
ensured that all of her questions about his clinical status and 
our medical care were answered to the best of our ability. She 
thanked the ICU team for the care he had received during his 
brief ICU stay. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Unknown
 
Discharge Medications:
Expired
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Mr. ___ died during his brief ICU stay - he was expired at 
the time of discharge
 
Discharge Condition:
Expired
 
Discharge Instructions:
Expired

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have a left proximal humerus fracture and a left femoral neck 
fracture and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The 
patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for left hip 
hemiarthroplasty, which the patient tolerated well. For full 
details of the procedure please see the separately dictated 
operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU 
in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from 
anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was 
initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications. The patient 
was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per 
routine. On POD1 the patient was started on a lovenox to 
___ for anticoagulation. On POD2 the patient was 
noted to have an acute kidney injury (Cr 1.4 to 2.0) and 
hyperkalemia to 6.1. The perioperative medicine team was 
consulted for assistance with management and intravenous fluids 
were started upon their recommendation. An EKG was obtained 
which revealed her baseline atrial fibrillation without change 
from her admission EKG. The patient endorsed mild nausea but 
denied chest pain or difficulty breathing. Her vital signs were 
within normal and she had no new oxygen requirement. A repeat 
set of labs was drawn which that her hyperkalemia had come down 
to 5.3 and her Cr had come down to 1.8. A half hour later, 
patient became bradycardic and had cardiac arrest. A code blue 
was initiated and full cardiac resuscitation was started. She 
was pronounced at 7:14pm.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ old woman with gastric adenocarcinoma. She 
presented to the hospital on ___ and underwent laparoscopic 
distal gastrectomy with Bilroth II reconstruction. For full 
details of this procedure, please refer to the separately 
dictated operative report. She appeared to tolerate the 
procedure well, and after a short and uneventful stay in the 
PACU, she was transferred to the surgical floor for further 
monitoring and recovery. NGT and Foley catheter were placed 
prior to the case and maintained post-operatively.

On POD#2, her NGT was removed and she was advanced to a clear 
liquid diet, then a regular (soft) diet as tolerated on POD#4 
after passage of flatus. When she was tolerating oral diet, PCA 
was discontinued and she was transitioned to oral pain 
medications. The foley catheter was removed on POD#2 and she was 
able to void. During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated 
early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and 
incentive spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of 
care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin during this 
stay. 

On POD#6 she was appropriate for discharge home. At the time of 
discharge she was tolerating a regular diet. Her pain was well 
controlled. She was able to ambulate without assistance. She 
will follow-up with Dr. ___ in clinic in two weeks and will 
continue on a soft diet and PPI until post-operative evaluation.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
for management of her menorrhagia. 

Outside hospital pelvic ultrasound showed multiple fibroids with 
largest one in the fundus measuring 3.9 x 3.3 x 4.3cm; normal 
right and left ovary with flow, no evidence of torsion. On 
presentation she was noted to have a hematocrit of 22.3. 

She was admitted and received 2 units of packed red blood cells 
for her symptomatic anemia. Her post-transfusion hematocrit was 
29 and patient remained asymptomatic. 

She was started on a cascading oral contraceptive pill regimen 
for management of her bleeding. She was also started on iron and 
Colace for management of her anemia. 

By HD#2, she was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating 
independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. 
She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient 
follow-up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ was admitted to the ACS service after he was seen as a 
trauma activation.  Please see the trauma sheet for initial H&P. 
 He was admitted to the ICU for frequent neuro checks given 
intoxication with alcohol and cocaine.  He remained neuro intact 
throughout his stay and did not have any acute changes requiring 
repeat imaging.  Tertiary survery was performed and negative for 
additional injuries.  Social work was consulted for alcohol 
dependence counseling.  Neurosurgery was consulted and 
recommended 7 days of Keppra and follow up in concussion clinic 
as needed.  At the time of discharge he was neuro intact, pain 
was well controlled, and was ambulating and voiding 
independently.  He will follow up with PCP for staple removal 
and concussion clinic as needed.

Discharge Instructions:
Surgery
Your dressing may come off on the third day after surgery. 
Your incision is closed with sutures. You will need suture. 
Please keep your incision dry until suture removal.
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

on the floor hemodynamically stable.

medication with continued good effect. Diet was progressively 
advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. 
The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, 
the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with 
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively 
participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay. 
 
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

delivery. Her course was complicated by uterine atony in the

including voiding, ambulating, and tolerating a regular diet.

follow up.

baths and dressing changes of the wound every other day. His

ranges. Her urine output ranged between ___ and her

increased to 1.5 later that day. AT ___ on ___, her

Brief Hospital Course:
She had a spontaneous vacuum assisted vaginal delivery on ___. 
Her placenta delivered spontaneously with a cord avulsion. 
Placenta noted for 20% abruption and patient repaired after deep 
sulcal lacerations noted. Estimated blood loss was noted to be 
1L. Patient received methergine and her vagina was packed with 4 
raytecs. Her Hct was trended and dropped from 32.7 pre-delivery 
to 21.1 later in the evening. She was tachycardic secondary to 
her blood loss and had an EKG which showed sinus tachycardia. 
Patient initially declined transfusion because felt well. After 
syncopal episode on PPD1, patient agreed to blood transfusion. 
She received 1 unit of packed red blood cells and reported 
marked improvement in symptoms including improvement in energy. 
Her tachycardia improved and her heart rate was within normal 
limits.

She thus underwent an uncomplicated postpartum course. Her 
vaginal bleeding was within normal limits. She tolerated a 
regular diet, voided spontaneously without issue, and ambulated 
independently. By postpartum day 2 after vaginal delivery, she 
was deemed stable for discharge with a plan set for postpartum 
follow up.

and a headache. Your blood pressures were monitored and remained

We think it is now safe for you to go home.

scans

 - abdominal pain  
 - increased swelling in your legs  
 - vision changes  
 - Worsening, painful or regular contractions  
 - Vaginal bleeding  
 - Leakage of water or concern that your water broke

 - Fever, chills

 - Other concerns

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Non weight bearing right lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take aspirin 325mg daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower but do no get your splint wet. No baths or 
swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples and splint that need to be removed 
will be taken out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted for overnight observation due to the 
nitrite positive nature of her urinalysis concerning for 
infection in context of potentially obstructing ureteral stone. 
Urology team had extensive discussion regarding benefits and 
risks of stent placement. Placement of a ureteral stent was 
desired to be avoided unless clinically necessary. Patient had 
no fevers or signs/symptoms of sepsis overnight. Her pain was 
easily controlled with oral medications. She had no nausea or 
vomiting and tolerated a regular diet meal prior to discharge. 
She was determined safe to be discharged on oral antibiotics. 
She understand she will need to come back to emergency room 
immediately if she develops fever, worsening pain, oral 
intolerance, or rigors/chills.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral 
salpingectomy for symptomatic fibroid uterus. Please see the 
operative report for full details.

Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with Dilaudid PCA/IV Toradol.

On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her 
foley was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was 
advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to 
oxycodone/ibuprofen/acetaminophen).

By post-operative day 2, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with 
any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 
weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
management of perforated antibiotics. You were given IV 
antibiotics and transitioned to oral antibiotics, which you will 
need to continue taking for ___ days. You are recovering well 
and are now ready for discharge. Please follow the instructions 
below to continue your recovery:
MEDICATIONS: 
Please take all medications as prescribed. It is very important 
to complete the course of antibiotics. 

ACTIVITY: 
   
 o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency. 
 o You may climb stairs.  
 o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit. 
 o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. 

   
 HOW YOU MAY FEEL:  
 o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. 
 o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in 
your throat during surgery. 
 o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed. 
 o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing. 
 o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.

admitted for empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis w/ IV 
abx (CTX and vancomycin).

for possible nidus of CNS infection. ENT consulted; scope showed 
no evidence of sinusitis.

which were at least contributing to cervical/head pain. Started 
on tizanidine. ___ evaluated pt for possible limitations due to 
pain; evaluated her as not needing further therapy at this time.

(___). Abx were discontinued.

Pt was discharged to f/up w/ primary care and w/ Neurology.

Transitional issues:
Pt was given rx for amitriptyline to be started if head and 
cervical pain requires acetaminophen and ibuprofen more often 
than half of the days of the week.
We recommend that pt have serum Tb test obtained to r/o the 
possibility of Tb infection as cause.

showed an elevated white count and thus you were started on

thus the antibiotics were discontinued. For your associated neck 
pain you were started on a muscle relaxer tizanidine. We also 
will try you on a medication called amitriptyline for headache 
prevention.

We would like for you to still get one more blood test performed 
to test for tuberculosis, since sometimes chronic meningitis can 
be associated with this. Your PCP can perform this test.

outpatient neurology appointment for you. if you don't hear from

was discharged the next day with instructions to follow up with

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ G5 P2 who underwent an uncomplicated 
spontaneous vaginal delivery.  In the postpartum period, she was 
noted to have significant vaginal
bleeding.  She was evaluated on two separate occasions. On the 
first occasion, it was noted that the patient was passing large 
clots and had a continuous trickle.  Bedside manual evacuation 
demonstrated clot filling the lower uterine segment as well as 
trailing membranes.  After manual evacuation, an ultrasound was 
performed demonstrating a thin endometrial stripe.  Several 
hours passed, and upon the second
presentation, the patient was persistently found to have a slow 
trickle of blood.  Manual evacuation at the bedside demonstrated 
200 mL of additional bleeding as well as some retained 
membranes.  

Prior to proceeding to the operating room, the patient had 
received a total of 1000 mcg of Cytotec and TXA.  Given the 
continuous trickle of bleeding, the decision was made to proceed 
to the operating room for an exam
under anesthesia and ultrasound-guided suction D and C. Stat CBC 
and coags were ordered prior to the OR.  The patient was 
hemodynamically stable.  Prior to proceeding to the back, the 
patient's EBL was 1200 mL. The patient underwent an 
uncomplicated D&C under ultrasound guidance and placement of a 
bakri balloon. She received 2 units of packed red blood cells 
intra-op and her hematocrit was trended. Her Bakri placement and 
vaginal packing were removed by PPD1.

Patient was also febrile ___ and received IV 
ampicillin and gentamicin for 24hrs postpartum and remained 
afebrile.  

She thus underwent an uncomplicated postpartum course. Her 
vaginal bleeding was within normal limits. She tolerated a 
regular diet, voided spontaneously without issue, and ambulated 
independently. By postpartum day 2after vaginal delivery, she 
was deemed stable for discharge with a plan set for postpartum 
follow up.

Home

term intrauterine pregnancy
postpartum hemorrhage

bedside.

Discharge Instructions:
Total Shoulder Arthroplasty
 Post-Operative Instructions
(with/without Biceps Tenodesis)

Medications
You will be given a prescription for pain medicine.  The pain 
medication is a codeine derivative and should be taken as 
directed.  

Please take one full strength aspirin (325 mg) each day for six 
weeks to decrease the risk of having a complication related to a 
blood clot.

Please take a stool softener, like Colace (Docusate Sodium 
100mg), twice a day while taking narcotics to prevent 
constipation.

Dressing
Leave your dressing for 48 hours after your surgery.  After 48 
hours, you may remove your dressing.  LEAVE THE TAPE STRIPS OVER 
YOUR INCISIONS.  These will stay on for 1.5 to 2 weeks and will 
slowly peel off.

Showering
You may shower 48 hours after your surgery and get your 
incisions wet.  DO NOT immerse in a tub or pool for 7  10 days 
to avoid excessive scarring and risk of infection.

When you shower, let your arm hang at your side (Do NOT raise 
your arm).  

To wash under your arm, lean forward carefully and let your arm 
hang.  Using your other hand, wash under your operative arm.  Do 
NOT scrub the incision.  When you are done, stand up and let 
your arm hang at your side.  Pat yourself dry and put your sling 
on.

Ice Packs
Keep Ice Packs on at all times exchanging every hour while 
awake.  Icing is very important to decrease swelling and pain 
and improve mobility.  After 24 hours, continue to use the ice 3 
 4 times a day, 15  20 minutes each time to keep swelling to a 
minimum.

Activity
Take it easy.
Wear your sling. 
Keep your arm at your side at ALL TIMES  no reaching, 
grabbing or pulling with your operative arm.

When to Contact Us
If you experience severe pain that your pain medication does not 
help, please let us know. 

If you have a temperature over 101.5º, please contact our office 
at ___.

Mr. ___ was admitted to the ICU the morning of ___ for 
management of his head injury. CT Head had documented: 1) 
diffuse areas of gray-white matter differentiation loss in 
bilateral cerebral hemispheres consistent with ischemia with 
diffuse edema  and bilateral uncal herniation, 2) multiple 
subarachnoid hemorrhages with some extension into the sylvian 
fissures and bifrontal subdural hematomas measuring 6 mm 
maximally and with 3 mm of leftward midline shift and 3) a 
complex scalp fracture, displaced right parietal skull fracture 
fragment. There was no evidence of traumatic injury in CT C 
spine and CT Torso. 

A family meeting was held with members of the Trauma service and 
Neurosurgery service to discuss severe TBI and its prognosis. 
The family decided to make the patient CMO. The patient was 
pronounced deceased at 11.34 am.

Discharge Instructions:
Medicines
 
  *  Take your pain medicine the way your doctor tells you to. 
- - - Do not drink alcohol, drive, or use machinery while you 
are taking narcotic pain medicine.
- - - As your pain lessens, decrease the amount of pain medicine 
you are taking.
 
  *  Narcotic pain medicine can cause constipation. To make it 
easier to have a bowel movement:
- - - Drink extra water and other fluids like juice, tea, and 
broth.
- - - Take a stool softener like docusate.  Docusate is also 
called Colace. You can buy it over the counter.
 
 
Activity
 
  *  Do not lift more than 10 pounds for 6-to-8 weeks. Ten 
pounds is as heavy as a gallon of milk.
 
  *  Walking is encouraged.  Do not do any strenuous exercise 
like aerobics, running or weight lifting until your doctor says 
it is ok.
 
 
Incision Care
 
  *  You may shower.  Do not scrub your incision.  Gently wash 
with soapy water and pat your incision dry. 
 
  *  Do not take a bath, swim, or use a sauna for 2-to-3 weeks 
or until your incision is completely healed.
 
  *  It is ok to leave your incisions uncovered.  You may also 
cover them with dry gauze if your incisions are draining or to 
protect them from irritation.

You were admitted to the hospital for a small bowel obstruction. 
 Your obstruction has subsequently resolved after conservative 
management. You have tolerated a regular diet, are passing gas 
and your pain is controlled with pain medications by mouth. You 
may return home to finish your recovery.  
 
If you have any of the following symptoms please call the office 
for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: increasing 
abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, nausea, 
vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, prolonged loose 
stool, or extended constipation.  

If your have any abdominal symptoms please call ___ and

admitted to ___. If there is an emergency you can go to ___ 
___ and be transferred to ___. 
 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. 

Good luck!

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing robot assisted 
laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. The patient received perioperative antibiotic 
prophylaxis. The patient was transferred to the floor from the 
PACU in stable condition. On POD0, pain was well controlled on 
PCA, hydrated for urine output >30cc/hour, provided with 
pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis, and 
ambulated once.  

On POD1, the patient was restarted on home medications, basic 
metabolic panel and complete blood count were checked, pain 
control was transitioned from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was 
advanced to a clears/toast and crackers diet. On POD2, JP and 
urethral Foley catheter were removed without difficulty and diet 
was advanced as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course 
was relatively unremarkable. The patient was discharged in 
stable condition, eating well, ambulating independently, voiding 
without difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On 
exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of 
hematoma collection or infection. The patient was given explicit 
instructions to follow-up in clinic in four weeks.

low transverse cesarean section for arrest of descent in second 
stage. Her post partum course was complicated by

hypertension

Regarding her chorioamnionitis, she received a gentamicin 24hour

surgical bleeding and intermittent atony. She received pitocin

and her post operative hct was 30.2.

four hours apart on ___. PIH labs were sent and within normal 
limits. She otherwise had normal to mild range BPs throughout 
the rest of her stay.

ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted for concern for partial small bowel 
obstrcuction. He was kept NPO and an NGT was placed. The NGT 
became dislodged on his first night in the hospital but his 
symptoms of nausea and abdominal pain had already resolved and 
he was pasing flatus so it was left out. ON hospital day one he 
was pasing flatus and his diet was advanced to clear which he 
tolerated. Ct noted a slight tightness of the fascia at the 
level of stoma with fullness of the loop so a foley catheter was 
placed into the stoma for decompression. This subsequently fell 
out and was left out. on hospital day 2 the patient tolerated 
regular diet and had formed bowel movements. He was ambulating 
at baseline and making good urine. at that time it was felt safe 
for him to discharge home with instructions to follow up in Dr. 
___ this week for a discussion regarding his tight 
stomal fascia with concern for loop dilation.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted as a transfer of care from an outside 
hospital after a spontaneous preterm vaginal delivery at 22 
weeks. Given her fundal tenderness and leukocytosis on 
admission, she was treated with ampicillin and gentamicin for 24 
hours for chorioamnionitis. Blood cultures were also drawn and 
her vital signs were closely monitored. She remained afebrile 
during her admission. She was seen by Social Work during her 
hospitalization. 

Her pain was treated with oral pain medications. She was 
maintained on a regular diet. By hospital day 3, she was 
tolerating a regular diet, ambulating independently, and pain 
was controlled with oral medications. She was afebrile with 
stable vital signs. She was then discharged home in stable 
condition with postpartum outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ underwent repeat low transverse 
C-section. 

On post-partum day 1 she experienced an episode of tachycardia 
and shortness of breath. She underwent EKG which showed sinus 
tachycardia and no evidence of ischemia. Chest x-ray showed 
bibasal opacities likely atelectasis, cannot rule out PE. CTA 
showed no evidence of PE, but was notable for ground glass 
opacities. Her CBC and electrolytes were normal. Her tachycardia 
improved during her admission. She remained afebrile with 
otherwise normal vital signs. She also experienced dysuria, and 
had a negative urinalysis. She was given Lovenox daily for DVT 
prophylaxis.

Her pain was treated with oral pain medications. She ambulated 
and her foley was discontinued and she voided spontaneously. Her 
diet was advanced without incident. 

By postpartum day 4, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent a primary low transverse caesarean delivery 
on ___ for breech presentation, gestational hypertension, type 
II diabetes mellitus and a non-reactive NST. During her 
postpartum course, her antihypertensive medications were 
up-titrated from 200 labetalol BID (antepartum regimen) to 
Labetalol 400mg Q8H plus Nifedipine 30mg QD. Her PIH labs were 
within normal limits including her urine protein: creatinine 
ratio. On postpartu day 3, patient began to complain about 
vision changes with a new onset headache in the setting of 
persistently severe range blood pressure. Decision was made to 
transfer to L&D for magnesium. She continued on magnesium for 24 
hours with resolution of headache and vision changes.

The remainder of her postpartum course was routine. She 
ambulated and her foley was discontinued and she voided 
spontaneously. Her diet was advanced without incident. 
By postpartum day 5, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 You were admitted to the hospital with leaking fluid concerning

 - vision changes

 - Other concerns
