On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the postpartum service 
status post a primary low transverse cesarean section for arrest 
of descent. Please see operative report for full details. 

In brief, Ms. ___ is a ___ G1P1 status post a low 
transverse cesarean section complicated by chorioamnionitis and 
intraoperative hemorrhage from uterine atony. She was treated 
with gentamicin and clindamycin for 24 hours postpartum. She was 
not treated with ampicillin given prior anaphylaxis reaction to 
cefazolin. She remained afebrile throughout her postpartum 
course.

1 unit pRBCs. Her post-transfusion hematocrit was 30. Her vital 
signs remained stable following the transfusion.   

By postpartum day 4, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient 
follow-up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
Her postpartum course was complicated by a readmission for 
pre-eclampsia severe by headaches and BPs. She received 24 hours 
of magnesium postpartum. PIH labs were ordered and showed 
elevated ALT to 46 and Uric Acid of 6.4. Labs were otherwise 
normal. Neurology was consulted for her headache. They felt 
there was low suspicion for an acute intracranial process but 
recommended a MRA/MRV. Her MRA/MRV was unremarkable. She 
received two doses of IV Hydralazine for severe range BPs and 
required no further anti-hypertensives agents. Her pain was 
treated with oral pain medications. She ambulated and her foley 
was discontinued and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was 
advanced without incident. 

By postpartum day #10, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
PNV, Insulin Humalog (4 units at breakfast, 3 units at
lunch, 3 units at dinner)

headache

with lower abdominal pain. She had been transferred to the 
emergency room from an outside hospital with concern for ovarian 
torsion secondary to a large left complex adnexal mass. Her

flow to both ovaries. The Acute Care Service was consulted and 
did not feel her pain was caused by diverticulitis or

normal limits.

regular diet. Her abdominal pain was localized to the umbilical 
hernia, with minimal concern for other abdominal or gynecologic 
etiology. She was discharged in stable condition with both 
general surgery and gynecology follow up appointments scheduled.

On ___, Ms. ___ underwent a repeat lower transverse 
cesarean section for newly diagnosed gestational hypertension. 
PIH labs were within normal limits except for a platelet count 
of 92. 

Her postpartum course is detailed as follows. For her history of 
GDMA2, she had finger stick blood glucose for 24 hours which 
were all normal in the postpartum period. On PPD#4, she 
developed severe range blood pressure of 169/74 and headache. 
She was given nifedipine 10mg with repeat BP 140s/60s. Repeat 
PIH labs were within normal limits. She was started on labetalol 
200mg BID on ___. On ___ she was uptitrated to labetalol 300mg 
TID for severe range pressures of 160s/70s. Her pressures were 
still severe range at 166/80 although patient was noted to be 
asymptomatic. Her labetalol dose was uptitrated to 400mg TID and 
had mild range blood pressures by PPD#6. She continued to be 
asymptomatic and was instructed to follow up with her PCP ___ 2 
days for blood pressure check. 

By postpartum day 6, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
Upon presentation, was intubated with GCS 3T. NCHCT did not show 
evidence of diffuse cerebral edema. However, She displayed 
seizure like activity in trauma bay, and EEG initiated upon 
arrival to the ICU as well as cooling protocol for cardiac 
arrest. Neurology was consulted and she was initiated on 
anti-seizure medications as well as sedation. After cooling 
protocol was completed and patient was warmed, the patient was 
noted to have some brainstem reflexes but no meaningful neuro 
exam was appreciated when weaned from sedation. Daily family 
meetings were held, and the decision was made to transition the 
patient to comfort care and code status was confirmed as DNR. 
___ Organ Bank was contacted regarding possibility of 
organ donation, but they ultimately declined.

On ___ she was terminally extubated and passed away the 
evening of ___.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with an impacted stone in your 
ureter. You had severe hypotension (low blood pressure), so 
urology placed a stent to allow proper drainage of your bladder. 
You should make an appointment with a urologist as soon as you 
get home. You will need to have your stent removed. In the 
meantime, please finish five additional days of antibiotics. 
Please continue tamsulosin, ibuprofen for pain, and pyridium for 
symptoms until you follow up with your urologist and have the 
stent removed. You may need lithotripy (breaking up of the 
stone) if it has not passed naturally, but this will be decided 
by your urologist.

Pt expired at 15:57 on ___.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was transferred to the ___ ED on ___. In the ED she was 
tachypneic and clearly had SIRS, abdominal distension and 
oliguria. Workup for sepsis, PE and abdominal catastrophe 
ensued. She was treated with IVF fluid and abx. During her ED 
stay, she had a large volume emesis, cardiac arrest and a 15 min 
period of resuscitation. She had return of circulation after 15 
mins and was stable enough for CT scanning.

CT showed a possible small bowel volvulus, but no threatened 
bowel. There was no obvious PE.

Discussion with GU, colorectal surgery and the ICU teams 
suggested she be stabilized after her arrest and reassessed for 
operative intervention in the AM.

Overnight she was cooled, but had progressive generalized 
seizure activity and myoclonus, despite anti-seizure agents.

After a thorough discussion with neurology and the family, a 
decision was made to withdraw support and make her CMO.

She expired peacefully at 15:57.

The family consented to an autopsy.

Discharge Instructions:
You came in today for drainage a fluid collection in your 
pelvis. You were taken to the OR where we drained the fluid 
collection and placed a small drain. Please follow these 
instructions. 

** Please  monitor  your  incision  lines  closely  for  signs  
of  infection:  opening  of  the  incision,  increased redness,  
increased  pain,  if  you  have  a  fever  greater  than  101,  
swelling of  the  tissues  around  the  incision line,  drainage 
 of  green/yellow/grey/white/thick  drainage,  increased  pain  
at  the  incision  line,  or  increased warmth.   
**You may resume normal activity and diet
**Please keep the drain in place until you follow up with Dr. 
___ in 1 week 
**You may continue to take your home medications including your 
warfarin.

Call your doctor or return to the Emergency Department right 
away if any of the  following problems develop:  

* You have more swelling, redness, drainage or bleeding.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 102 degrees 
(F)
* You have significant or worsening pain in the area of your 
abscess.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ underwent an uncomplicated spontaneous 
vaginal delivery. For her gestational hypertension, she was not 
on any medications and did not receive magnesium. 

On postpartum day 2, she endorsed dyspnea on exertion and 
weakness. A hematocrit was drawn which was 28.0, and her exam 
was benign and not concerning for cardiopulmonary disease. She 
was observed overnight and felt better in the morning. 

Her postpartum course was uncomplicated. Her pain was treated 
with oral pain medications. She ambulated and her foley was 
discontinued and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was advanced 
without incident. 

By postpartum day 3, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Antepartum course
==================
Ms. ___ is a gravida 6 para 2 who was admitted to the ___ 
antepartum unit on ___ at 24 weeks 4 days gestation.  
Rupture of membranes was confirmed by speculum exam and she was 
consulted by the NICU.  She was started on latency antibiotics 
with azithromycin and ampicillin followed by amoxicillin.  She 
was started on acyclovir given a history of genital HSV.  She 
received a course of betamethasone for fetal lung benefit.

She underwent an ultrasound at the ___ maternal-fetal 
medicine showing an infant 898 g 71st percentile.  For the 
following 6 days she remained inpatient and stable on latency 
antibiotics. 

On ___ she developed painful contractions and was found to 
be progressing in preterm labor. She was transferred to labor 
and delivery where she was magnesium for fetal neuro protection 
started on and subsequently delivered a viable male infant 
vaginally without complication.  Please see OMR for complete 
details

In the postpartum she recovered well.  By postpartum day 1 she 
was tolerating regular diet, pain was controlled on oral 
medication, ambulating without difficulty, and lochia was 
minimal.  She elected to be discharged and was so in ambulatory 
condition with postpartum follow-up scheduled.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER HAND SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for hand surgery. It is normal to 
feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- range of motion as tolerated
- please do not resume work for 1 week

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- none

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please change your dressing twice daily with a moist dressing 
(wet to dry). 

Physical Therapy:
range of motion as tolerated

The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the hand surgery team. The patient was found to 
have concern for left index finger flexor tenosynovitis and was 
admitted to the hand surgery service. The patient was taken to 
the operating room on ___ for irrigation and debridement 
of the left index finger flexor tendon sheath, which the patient 
tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were 
continued throughout this hospitalization. The ___ 
hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

The patient was also evaluated and followed by the infectious 
disease service.  His intraoperative cultures grew GAS. he was 
initially maintained on vancomycin and Zosyn for empiric 
antibiotics and was eventually narrowed to Augmentin.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
weightbearing and activity as tolerated in the left upper 
extremity. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ 
routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient 
regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course 
including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, 
and all questions were answered. The patient was also given 
written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and 
the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness 
for discharge.

unclear etiology and unstable tachycardia requiring 
cardioversion in the ED. Given the situation her family felt 
that transition to comfort focused care was most appropriate.

died peacefully on ___ with her family at bedside.

Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with a short cervix and had a 
cervical cerclage. You were observed in the antepartum service, 
and received antibiotics for 24 hours after your procedure. We 
also gave you a medicine to prevent preterm contractions 
(indomethacin). You had no evidence of infection or preterm 
labor, it is now safe for you to be discharged home.

pregnancy***
-other than your vaginal progesterone, avoid placing anything in 
the vagina
-avoid douching, avoid tampons
-avoid vaginal sex
-avoid anal sex

 - Vaginal bleeding

 - Nausea/vomiting  
 - Fever, chills  
 - Other concerns

Discharge Instructions:
Medicines
 
  *  Take your pain medicine the way your doctor tells you to. 
- - - Do not drink alcohol, drive, or use machinery while you 
are taking narcotic pain medicine.
- - - As your pain lessens, decrease the amount of pain medicine 
you are taking.
 
  *  Narcotic pain medicine can cause constipation. To make it 
easier to have a bowel movement:
- - - Drink extra water and other fluids like juice, tea, and 
broth.
- - - Take a stool softener like docusate.  Docusate is also 
called Colace. You can buy it over the counter.
 
 
Activity
 
  *  Do not lift more than 10 pounds for 6-to-8 weeks. Ten 
pounds is as heavy as a gallon of milk.
 
  *  Walking is encouraged.  Do not do any strenuous exercise 
like aerobics, running or weight lifting until your doctor says 
it is ok.
 
 
Incision Care
 
  *  You may shower 48 hours after surgery.  Do not scrub your 
incision.  Gently wash with soapy water and pat your incision 
dry. 
 
  *  Do not take a bath, swim, or use a sauna for 2-to-3 weeks 
or until your incision is completely healed.
 
  *  It is ok to leave your incisions uncovered.
  * Wear your compression garment at all times.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old man with complicated 
structuring and penetrating Crohn's disease, with multiple 
fistulae and recurrent small bowel obstructions, who presented 
with abdominal pain and last BM morning of ___.

# Crohn's Disease
# C/f Small Bowel Obstruction
He was seen by colorectal surgery and GI in the ED and underwent 
labs and CT A/P which showed no acute inflammation, no clear 
radiologic evidence of obstruction. He was recommended for 
admission to medicine for conservative management. On arrival to 
the floor, he had no abdominal pain, no nausea or vomiting. 
Initially, he was not passing flatus, but later began doing so. 
He was disappointed to find he had a double-room and felt that 
this put him at risk of poor rest, increased infection risk, and 
that he has difficulty having bowel movements in public. He 
requested to leave and monitor his symptoms at home. GI and 
Colorectal surgery saw him on the floor and agreed he was stable 
for discharge.

On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophrectomy. Please see the operative report for full 
details.

Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with IV dilaudid/toradol. She 
had decreased urine output, and was given IV fluids with 
improvement in urine output. 

On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her 
foley was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was 
advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to 
oxycodone/acetaminophen/ibuprofen(pain meds).

By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___ ,

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with 
any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 3 
months.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

neck stiffness which was initially concerning for meningitis vs. 
epidural abscess vs. atypical migraines. Her labs were notable 
for normal WBC count. She was seen by Neurology and Anesthesia 
teams. She underwent lumbar puncture and was started on empiric 
therapy for meningitis (IV vancomycin, cefepime and acyclovir). 
CSF fluid revealed no evidence of infection, so antibiotics were 
stopped. She underwent a chest x-ray which showed  Small pleural 
fluid, no infiltrates, and bilateral oligemia in the upper 
lungs. Her CTPA was negative for PE, and had mild centrilobular 
emphysema. Per neurology recommendations, she underwent a head 
CT which showed no acute process, and an MRI spine showed no 
evidence of epidural abscess. MRI of the head was negative for 
venous sinus thrombosis, however had a finding of Chiari 
malformation with no syringohydromyelia. Neurology recommended 
outpatient follow-up.

For her headache she was given IV hydration and fioricet. She 
also developed chest pain, which resolved on its own. Troponins 
were negative, and EKG showed no evidence of ischemia. A repeat 
EKG the next day was stable. Repeat labs were again negative for 
leukocytosis, and lactate was found to be downtrending. Flu 
testing and UA and urine culture were negative.

By postpartum day 7, her pain was well-controlled with oral 
medications, her neck stiffness and tenderness was improving, 
and she was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating independently. 
She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was then 
discharged home in stable condition with postpartum outpatient 
follow-up scheduled.

pre-natal vitamins

maturity and you were counseled by the NICU team. All of your 
fetal testing and ultrasounds have been reassuring.  We think it

scans

 - abdominal pain  
 - increased swelling in your legs  
 - vision changes  
 - Worsening, painful or regular contractions  
 - Vaginal bleeding  
 - Leakage of water or concern that your water broke

 - Fever, chills  
 - Decreased fetal movement  
 - Other concerns

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you had an infection 
to the skin on your legs. You had a blood culture drawn at your 
primary care doctor's office that grew Bacillus (not anthracis), 
that was likely a contaminant. You had repeat blood cultures 
drawn here that did not grow anything. You had 2 days of IV 
antibiotics, and then you were restarted on the oral antibiotics 
that your PCP had prescribed to you.

Please call your PCP if you feel that your symptoms are 
worsening again (swelling, redness, drainage). 
Continue to take your antibiotics until the end. 

It was a pleasure taking care of you!

-Your ___ Care team.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service ___ for 
observation for an ectopic pregnancy. She was being followed for 
a known tubal ectopic pregnancy, having received 3 doses of 
methotrexate. She initially presented with worsening abdominal 
pain and vaginal bleeding, so was admitted for observation. Her 
vitals and exam were remarkable for minimal abdominal 
tenderness. Her pelvic ultrasound showed some blood around the 
tubal mass, with trace fluid in the abdomen, but she required no 
further pain medication and her hematocrit remained stable 
overnight. Her hCG levels decreased as well. Our working 
diagnosis is tubal abortion.  Given her improved status and 
benign abdominal exam on discharge and stable vital signs 
throughout her hospitalization, she was discharged home with 
close follow-up to continue trending HCG levels to 0 under the 
Chief Resident Service's care.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service because of a concern 
that your ectopic pregnancy ruptured. You were counseled 
extensively on this risk and the possible need for surgical 
intervention. You elected for conservative management. Your red 
blood cell levels remained stable and your beta-hCG level 
decreased appropriately. Your clinical exam remained stable as 
well and we felt comfortable discharging you home, with close 
follow-up and strict precautions. We recommend you call the 
clinic immediately if you experience any of the following:

- sharp or radiating abdominal pain
- increasing abdominal pain
- increased vaginal bleeding
- nausea or vomiting
- fever to greater than 100.4
- dizziness or lightheadness
- if you become severely short of breath or have chest pain

As part of your follow up, we recommend obtaining a serum hCG 
level in 1 week.

If you have any questions or concerns, please call ___ 
to speak to one of your medical providers.

secretions.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted for further management of his likely 
retained common bile duct stone. He was kept NPO and started on 
IV antibiotics. He was promptly taken for ERCP. He required 
sphincterotomy and a singular retained stone was swept from the 
common bile duct. A PD stent was placed.

He remained NPO overnight and the following morning his LFTs 
were improved. He was trialed on a regular diet and tolerated 
this with no pain. He was able to ambulate independently, void 
without issue, and tolerate a diet and as such the decision was 
made to discharge the patient home with follow up planned in 2 
weeks for PD stent removal. The patient was in agreement with 
this discharge plan.

25.3. She was no longer symptomatic. The remainder of her post 
partum course was uncomplicated and she was discharged home in 
stable condition with scheduled outpatient follow up.

Brief Hospital Course:
The Pt was taken to the OR with Dr ___ a right wrist 
fusion and shorteing of the radius and extensor tendons on 
___ and tolerated the procedure well.  Please see separately 
dictated operative note for details.  Post operatively, the 
patient recovered without event in the surgical pacu and later 
in the surgical ICU as secondary to her venous malformation she 
had significant oozing from the operative site postoperatively.  
This is standard for this patient.  The venous ooze generally 
slows down after several hours of the drain on continuous low 
wall suction, and thic can only be done in an ICU.  
FICU COURSE
Pt was transferred to the FICU after her procedure because her 
wound drain needed to be hooked up to wall suction, which cannot 
be accommodated on the floor. She remained stable overnight with 
no issues. She was continued of IV cefazolin. She had oxycodone, 
Tylenol, and dilaudid PCA for pain, which was well controlled. 
Her drain was put to bulb suction in the morning per hand 
surgery recommendations and continued to hold suction well with 
minimal output of only serosanguinous drainage. By the afternoon 
of POD1 her RUE block had worn off and pain was well controlled 
on PO pain meds.  She was eager for home.  

on the morning of POD1 she was pain controlled on PO pain meds, 
she was ambulating independently, tolerating a regular diet, and 
voiding without difficulty.  Her splint was removed and revealed 
an incision that was CDI without signs of hematoma.  The drain 
put out 100cc overnight and was slowing down and thinning out.  
It was transitioned to a bulb without event.  She expressed her 
readiness for home and was discharged to home in a healthy 
condition

his organized cardiac activity deteriorated into VT and no pulse

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

You were admitted to ___ with 
severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain and an elevated white 
blood count. You underwent several imaging studies which did not 
identify your appendix. The most recent CT scan demonstrated an 
infarction of your omentum (fat overlying the intestines). These 
infarctions can be extremely painful, but do not require any 
treatment. In addition, your CT scan showed bilateral pelvic 
lymphadenopathy (enlargement of the lymph nodes) which will need 
to be worked up further to rule out another cause, such as 
infection or malignancy. Please follow-up with the Thoracic 
Surgeon, Dr. ___ at the appointment listed below to 
discuss the findings on your prior chest CT scan. Please see 
your PCP to discuss these findings and determine which, if any, 
additional lab tests they would like to perform. You are 
recovering well and are now ready for discharge. 

Warm regards, 

Your ___ Surgery Team

___ is a ___ year old female on Coumadin for atrial 
fibrillation and was found to have a large left intraparenchymal 
hemorrhage.

#Intraparenchymal hemorrhage
While in the ED, the patient's INR was reversed with KCentra and 
Vitamin K. He was agitated and then had an acute change and 
became very calm. He was given a bolus of 3% HTS and was 
emergently taken to the operating room for left craniotomy for 
clot evacuation. The procedure was uncomplicated. For further 
procedure details, please see separately dictated operative 
report by Dr. ___. He was transported to the NICU. 
Post-operatively, he continued to have a poor neurological exam 
and STAT CTA was completed and significant for R ICA occlusion 
and R hemispheric infarction. EEG was placed. Code stroke was 
activated. MRI brain was performed and revealed complete 
infarction of the R MCA. Given the size, the patient was not a 
candidate for reperfusion. On ___, EEG was discontinued. His 
sodium uptrended and 3% HTS was decreased. There was a family 
meeting held on ___ and it was decided to proceed with comfort 
measures only. The patient was extubated in the evening. He 
passed away in the early morning of ___.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ underwent a forceps assisted vaginal 
delivery for cord prolapse. Her delivery was complicated by 
postpartum hemorrhage secondary to uterine atony. EBL was 600cc 
at time of delivery.  

After transfer to the postpartum floor, patient was noted to be 
hypotensive with persistent vaginal bleeding, totaling 500cc. 
Her hematocrit prior to delivery was 35.4. A repeat lab was 
drawn during active bleeding and was noted to be 20.6. She was 
consented and received 2 units packed red blood cells with 
repeat hematocrit 21.2. By PPD#1, patient was hemodynamically 
stable and on exam there was no evidence of vaginal hematoma or 
signs of retroperitoneal bleeding. 

By postpartum day 2, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Discharge Instructions

Activity
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity 
at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if you 
are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

Mr. ___ presented to the ED on ___ with  pleuritic chest 
pain. On CXR he was found to have a small-to-moderate sized

pneumothorax clinically and with serial imaging and not to place

extent of pneumothorax, and showed a small, stable left 
pneumothorax with bullous changes of the right pneumothorax. His 
vitals were routinely monitored and noted to be stable 
throughout the course of his hospital stay. He continued to have 
oxygen saturations in the high ___ on room air. His pain was 
well-controlled. He was deemed appropriate for discharge home 
with close follow-up. He was advised against heavy lifting 
during his recovery period.

evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have a right femur fracture and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. He was also found to be in severe

that dialysis was not within the patients goals of care.

to go into hypovolemic shock, required pressors, had increasing 
acidosis, hyperkalemia, as well as oliguric renal failure. 
Family decided to make the patient comfort measures only and the 
patient was declared dead from hypovolemic shock secondary to a 
R femur fracture on ___ at 1757.

autopsy, condolences offered, questions answered.

right carotid stent placement. Patient tolerated procedure well.

discussed with patient that if he stopped taking brillinta and

medical advice. Attempted to encourage patient to stay. Patient 
left hospital against medical advice.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with 
any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:
* You may take motrin and acetaminophen (Tylenol) for pain
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no sex, tampons, douching) for 1 month
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your follow-up visit.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

family (who were present in the ICU) made the decision not to

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ year old female who presented to the 
Emergency Department on ___ as a transfer from an outside 
facility after suddenly collapsing mid conversation at 15:45 at 
home. Patient was in cardiac arrest and cardiopulmonary 
resuscitation was initiated immediately by bystanders. Patient 
had return of spontaneous circulation within 10 minutes. When 
the patient arrived at the outside facility, she went into 
pulseless electrical activity twice, which required 
defibrillation. Patient had return of spontaneous circulation. 
There was concern initially that the cardiac arrest was 
secondary to a left anterior descending artery myocardial 
infarction given ST depressions on ECG, and patient received 
aspirin. CTA of the head at the outside facility revealed a 
right anterior communicating artery aneurysm rupture and 
subarachnoid hemorrhage. Patient was started on 3% hypertonic 
saline. Patient was also hypertensive and required vasopressors. 
Patient was transferred to ___ 
for further evaluation and treatment. The Neurosurgery Service 
was consulted for question of acute neurosurgical intervention.

- alcohol abuse
- depression 
- left knee prepatellar bursitis
- obesity

___

Unknown

-------------

light bilaterally.
Extremities: Cool to touch and pale throughout. 

Neurologic: Without sedation for approximately two hours. No eye 
opening to noxious. No corneal reflexes bilaterally. Pupils 2mm 
and nonreactive to light bilaterally. No gag reflex. No cough

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY
=======
___ is a ___ F with history of hidradenitis 
suppuritiva with symptoms poorly managed on Cimzia, ustekinumab 
who presents for planned remicaide desensitization. She 
underwent her desensitization procedure without incident and was 
discharged home with dermatology follow up.

ACUTE ISSUES 
============
# Remicaide allergy
# HS flare
Per Dr. ___ from ___, she will need at least 3 doses 
in the ICU and ongoing infusions in outpatient clinic as well. 
This is her third treatment in the ICU. The below information is 
from Dr. ___.
================================
- Recommend 12 Step 3 bag standard desensitization protocol for 
Remicade infusion with following premedication regimen
-30 min before
 -Cetirizine 10 mg PO
 -Famotidine 20 mg IV
 -Montelukast 10 mg PO
 -Aspirin 325 mg PO
 -Methyl Prednisolone 20 mg IV
 -Ativan 0.5 mg-1mg PO if requested by the patient
-Normal Saline 250 c/hr through out the desensitization 
protocol, increase to 500 cc/hr in case of a reaction
-Between step 8 and 9 give hydroxyzine 25 mg PO
-Procedure discussed with the patient in detail, risk and 
benefits discussed, patient expressed understanding
================================
In addition:
-last dose of methotrexate ___, continue 7.5 mg weekly with 
daily folic acid 1 mg po

CHRONIC ISSUES 
==============
# Crohn's disease
No current evidence of Crohn's flare.
- Infliximab infusion as above

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[] Follow up with Dermatology and Allergy as indicated

Discharge Instructions:
Please keep white steri strips in place as these will fall off 
on their own
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:  
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).  
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).  


3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF  
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.  . 

 Return to the ER if:   
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.   
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.  
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.  .

labor for PROM at 37w1d. She was started on pitocin and

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Herniated disc with nerve root compression

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental status: Alert and oriented, following complex commands
Ambulatory

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have a herniated disk which is compressing your nerve roots, 
giving you pain and weakness in your right leg. You will need 
surgery to remove the disc. In the meantime, please call us if 
you have any change in symptoms. Please return to the ___ 
emergency room if you have any of these:
- increased weakness, new weakness
- new numbness, tingling, pins & needles sensation in your legs
- numbness, tingling, pins & needles sensation in your groin, 
inside of our leg or in genital area
- incontinence of urine or of stool
- urinary retention, inability to pee

Please avoid any strenuous activities until the time of your 
surgery. Absolutely no lifting or running.

Steroids:
Please take your steroid taper exactly as outlined below. This 
is extremely important. You have received 2 doses of steroids 
already in the hospital. You will be given 2mg pills. Take the 
correct number of pills for the prescribed dose.
- This evening, take 4mg of dexamethasone and then 8 hours 
later, take one more dose of 4mg.
- 8 hours after that dose, decrease to 2mg dexamethasone. Take 
2mg x4 doses all 8 hours apart.
- After 4 total doses at of 2mg 8 hours apart, take 2mg x4 doses 
12 hours apart.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
Overnight on POD#0, the patient had a fever to 102.8.  
Urinalysis was mildly positive, therefore the patient was 
started on a 3-day course of Cipro.  Blood cultures showed ***.  
She required oxygen supplementation on POD#1.  Due to her new 
oxygen requirement and fevers, a CTA was ordered.  The CTA was 
negative.  On POD#2, her urine culture came back negative and 
her Cipro was discontinued.

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received lovenox for DVT 
prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The foley was 
removed and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. 
The surgical dressing was changed and the Silverlon dressing was 
removed on POD#2. The surgical incision was found to be clean 
and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity. 
 
Ms ___ is discharged to home in stable condition.

2. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild 
3. coenzyme Q10 100 mg oral DAILY

Brief Hospital Course:
While in the ED, the differential included biliary colic versus 
acute cholecystitis. Ultrasound was overall unchanged from 
previous. However, when pain did not improve and the patient was 
unable to tolerate PO, in the setting of a mild leukocytosis, 
the decision was made to proceed with cholecystectomy. The 
patient was agreeable to this plan. 

On ___ the patient was taken to the operating room and 
underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The procedure was 
uncomplicated, please see the operative report for more details. 
After an uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient was 
transferred to the surgical floor for continued monitoring. On 
POD#1, the patient was tolerating a diet, pain was controlled, 
was voiding and ambulating. She was determined to be appropriate 
for discharge. She will follow-up in two weeks.
